wiki_catalogs.name: Project Overview
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the code-speeder project. Explain its purpose as a Next.js-based frontend application designed for audio recording, visualization, and potential transcription integration. Describe the high-level architecture using React 19, Next.js App Router, and TypeScript, emphasizing the component-driven design with shadcn/ui and Radix UI primitives. Document the relationship between core modules: UI components in src/components/ui, custom hooks for audio and clipboard functionality, and utility functions in src/lib. Highlight key features such as real-time audio visualization, responsive design, and developer tooling (Biome, pnpm, Docker). Include practical examples from the codebase, such as how page.tsx integrates components and hooks. Address common setup issues and performance considerations for audio processing in browser environments.

wiki_catalogs.name: Audio Recording
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Audio Recording sub-system. Thoroughly explain the implementation of the useAudioRecording custom hook and its integration with the MediaStream and MediaRecorder Web APIs. Document the state management logic for recording lifecycle (idle, recording, stopped), including permission handling, error recovery, and stream cleanup to prevent memory leaks. Detail the recordAudio utility function from audio-utils.ts, focusing on its asynchronous Blob generation, MIME type configuration (audio/webm;codecs=opus), and internal MediaRecorder management. Include concrete code examples showing how to invoke the hook in components, handle recording start/stop, and manage the resulting audio blob. Explain the stop method's role in terminating active recordings and releasing resources. Address common issues such as browser permission denials, unsupported MIME types, and handling of inactive recorder states. Provide best practices for ensuring reliable recording across different browsers and devices.

wiki_catalogs.name: Form Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for the form-related UI components in the code-speeder application. Describe how the Form component integrates with React Hook Form and Zod for validation, and explain the composition pattern used with Label, Input, Textarea, RadioGroup, Checkbox, and Select components. Document the role of the Field component as a container for form elements with structured labeling and content layout. Illustrate usage examples showing accessible form structures, error handling, and responsive behavior. Include details on OTP input handling via InputOTP and its part-based validation. Explain how class-variance-authority and cn utility are used for consistent styling across form controls. Address accessibility attributes inherited from Radix UI primitives and best practices for extending form components while maintaining type safety and validation integrity.

wiki_catalogs.name: Technology Stack & Dependencies
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the technology stack of code-speeder. Detail the role of each critical framework: Next.js 16 for App Router routing and server/client component model, React 19 with React Compiler for optimized rendering, TypeScript for type safety, and Tailwind CSS with class-variance-authority for styling. Explain the purpose of Radix UI primitives in building accessible, unstyled components and how they are extended via shadcn/ui patterns. Cover developer tools including Biome for linting/formatting, pnpm for package management, and Docker for containerization. Include configuration specifics from next.config.ts (e.g., compiler options) and tsconfig.json (path aliases). Provide examples of how these technologies integrate, such as 'use client' directives enabling client-side hooks. Address version compatibility, security considerations, and performance implications of the chosen stack.

wiki_catalogs.name: Audio Visualization
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for the Audio Visualizer UI component. Describe its purpose in providing real-time visual feedback during audio recording by rendering frequency or waveform data using Canvas or Web Audio API. Explain the component's props, expected data input (e.g., frequency arrays), and animation patterns using Framer Motion or similar libraries. Document integration with the audio recording system to display live microphone input levels. Include usage examples with code snippets demonstrating how to bind the visualizer to the recording state. Provide guidance on customization of visual appearance, color schemes, and responsiveness across screen sizes. Address accessibility considerations such as screen reader compatibility and performance optimization for smooth 60fps rendering during active recording. Discuss fallback strategies when Web Audio API is unavailable.

wiki_catalogs.name: Overlay Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop comprehensive documentation for overlay and modal UI components including Dialog, Drawer, Sheet, AlertDialog, Popover, Tooltip, and HoverCard. Explain the architectural differences between server-rendered and client-side behavior using 'use client' directives. Detail animation integration via Framer Motion and exit transitions. Document positioning strategies, accessibility features (ARIA roles, focus trapping), and event propagation handling. Provide usage examples for each component, highlighting key props like side placement in Sheet and Drawer, trigger interactions in Popover, and intent variants in AlertDialog. Illustrate how these components consume the cn utility for styling and integrate with next-themes for dark mode support. Address performance considerations around portal rendering, unmount behavior, and mobile responsiveness. Include troubleshooting guidance for common issues such as scroll locking, z-index conflicts, and touch interaction bugs.

wiki_catalogs.name: Getting Started Guide
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Getting Started Guide. Provide step-by-step instructions for setting up the development environment: installing dependencies with pnpm, running the dev server (pnpm dev), and accessing the app at localhost:3000. Include alternative setups using Docker (docker-compose up) for containerized development. Explain the purpose of key files like page.tsx for editing the main UI and globals.css for global styles. Document common setup issues such as missing dependencies, port conflicts on 3001 for production start, and Docker networking problems. Offer troubleshooting tips for Biome linting errors and TypeScript type issues. Highlight customization points such as modifying the theme in globals.css or adding new components via shadcn/ui patterns. Ensure the guide is accessible to beginners while providing sufficient technical depth for experienced developers.

wiki_catalogs.name: Transcription Integration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Transcription Integration pattern. Explain how the recorded audio Blob is processed and passed to external transcription services via callback mechanisms like transcribeAudio. Document the expected interface for transcription callbacks, including input parameters (Blob, metadata) and return types (Promise<string>). Detail the integration point within the recording lifecycle—specifically after recording stops and the Blob is generated. Include examples of implementing transcription with popular services (e.g., Web Speech API, Whisper, or cloud providers). Address error handling, loading states, and user feedback during transcription. Discuss data privacy implications when sending audio to external APIs and options for on-device processing. Provide guidance on type safety using TypeScript interfaces and async/await patterns for handling transcription results in the UI.

wiki_catalogs.name: Navigation Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for navigation and structural UI components including NavigationMenu, Sidebar, Tabs, Breadcrumb, Menubar, and Pagination. Explain how NavigationMenu implements accessible dropdown menus with keyboard navigation and viewport-aware positioning. Describe Sidebar's collapsible behavior, theming, and integration with responsive layouts. Document Tabs for content switching with ARIA-compliant tab panels. Illustrate Breadcrumb for hierarchical navigation with separator customization. Cover Menubar for application-level menu structures and Pagination for data set navigation. Show how these components use compound patterns, data attributes for styling, and Radix UI primitives for accessibility. Include examples of responsive adaptations using use-mobile hook and integration with layout.tsx. Address customization options via cva variants and best practices for SEO-friendly navigation structures.

wiki_catalogs.name: UI Component Library
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the UI component library in src/components/ui. Describe the design philosophy based on shadcn/ui and Radix UI primitives, emphasizing accessibility, composability, and styling via Tailwind CSS and class-variance-authority. Document the structure of compound components (e.g., Accordion, DropdownMenu) and atomic elements (e.g., Button, Input). Explain how cva is used in utils.ts to define variant classes and how these are consumed across components. Illustrate component composition patterns with examples like Form integrating Input, Label, and Button. Address responsive behavior, dark mode support via next-themes, and accessibility attributes from Radix. Include performance considerations for re-renders and best practices for extending components. Provide guidance on adding new components using the components.json configuration.

wiki_catalogs.name: Data Display Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop comprehensive documentation for data display and visualization components including Card, Table, Chart, Accordion, Badge, Progress, Slider, and typography elements. Explain Card's compound structure with Header, Title, Description, Content, Footer, and Action slots. Document Table's accessible markup, sorting indicators, and responsive handling. Describe Chart's integration point for data visualization (potentially tied to audio frequency data). Illustrate Accordion's controlled state management and animation behavior. Cover Badge variants (default, secondary, destructive, outline) and their semantic uses. Explain Progress and Slider components for value representation and user input, including multi-thumb support in Slider. Highlight how all components use the cn utility and Tailwind CSS variables for consistent theming. Provide examples of composing these components for dashboard-like interfaces and real-time data presentation, such as audio recording metrics.

wiki_catalogs.name: Audio System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the Audio System. Explain the architecture of audio recording using the MediaStream and MediaRecorder Web APIs, managed through the useAudioRecording custom hook. Detail the data flow from microphone input to Blob output, including permission handling, recording state management (idle, recording, stopped), and error handling. Describe the audio visualization component that renders real-time frequency data using Canvas or Web Audio API. Document the transcribeAudio callback pattern for integrating transcription services. Include implementation details from audio-utils.ts such as blob processing and MIME type handling. Provide usage examples showing how to integrate the hook into components. Address common issues like microphone access denial, browser compatibility, and memory leaks from active streams. Offer performance optimization tips for large audio blobs and real-time rendering.

wiki_catalogs.name: Feedback Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for user feedback and state communication components including Alert, Sonner (toast notifications), Spinner, Skeleton, Empty state, and Toast. Explain Alert's intent variants (default, destructive, success) and icon integration via Lucide. Document Sonner's API for programmatic toast dispatching, theming, and stacking behavior. Describe Spinner's animation mechanics and size variants for loading states. Illustrate Skeleton for content loading placeholders with shimmer effects. Cover Empty state component for representing void data scenarios with illustrative content. Show how these components support dark mode via CSS variables and ensure accessibility through proper ARIA live regions and focus management. Provide usage patterns for integrating feedback components with audio recording workflows, form submissions, and asynchronous operations. Include performance tips for minimizing re-renders during frequent toast updates.

wiki_catalogs.name: State Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for state management in code-speeder. Focus on the use of custom React hooks to encapsulate stateful logic: useAudioRecording for managing recording state, useMobile for responsive behavior detection, and useCopyToClipboard for clipboard operations. Explain how useState and useEffect are used within these hooks to manage lifecycle and side effects. Document the public interfaces—returned values, setter functions, and event callbacks—and how they are consumed by UI components. Illustrate state flow with examples such as the audio recording button toggling states or mobile detection altering layout. Address common issues like stale closures, memory leaks from event listeners, and race conditions in async operations. Provide best practices for creating reusable, testable hooks with proper TypeScript typing.

wiki_catalogs.name: Layout Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop documentation for layout utility components including Resizable, AspectRatio, ScrollArea, and Container. Explain Resizable's drag-based dimension control with horizontal/vertical constraints and event callbacks. Document AspectRatio for maintaining proportional media containers using padding hacks or modern CSS. Describe ScrollArea's cross-browser scroll styling with overlay scrollbars and momentum scrolling on macOS. Illustrate Container's role in defining content width boundaries and responsive breakpoints. Show how these components leverage Radix UI primitives for accessibility and performance. Provide examples of using Resizable in split-pane interfaces, AspectRatio for audio waveform canvases, and ScrollArea for transcript displays. Address integration with flex/grid layouts and responsiveness across device sizes. Include guidance on avoiding layout thrashing and optimizing scroll performance for large content.

wiki_catalogs.name: Responsive Design & Mobile Support
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed content for responsive design and mobile optimization. Explain how useMobile hook detects device type using window.matchMedia and enables adaptive UI rendering. Document the use of resizable components for desktop layouts and touch-friendly controls for mobile. Cover CSS strategies in globals.css for viewport handling, touch targets, and orientation support. Include examples of conditional rendering based on device type and responsive breakpoints using Tailwind. Address challenges like touch vs. mouse interactions, keyboard navigation on mobile, and performance of visualizations on lower-end devices. Provide testing strategies for cross-device compatibility and accessibility considerations for touch interfaces.

wiki_catalogs.name: Input Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for interactive input components including Button, Input, Textarea, Switch, Toggle, ToggleGroup, and FilePreview. Explain Button variants (default, destructive, outline, secondary, ghost, link) and sizes (default, sm, lg, icon) using cva. Document Input and Textarea with support for prefixes, suffixes via InputGroup, and validation states. Describe Switch and Toggle for boolean inputs with animated transitions. Illustrate ToggleGroup for mutually exclusive selections. Cover FilePreview for displaying uploaded file metadata and thumbnails, potentially used for audio file attachments. Show how these components integrate with form systems, handle focus states, and support keyboard navigation. Include examples of composing Button with Icon components from Lucide, and using InputOTP for multi-digit verification. Address accessibility requirements, loading states, and mobile touch targets.

wiki_catalogs.name: Accessibility Features
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content focused on accessibility in the code-speeder application. Highlight how Radix UI primitives provide built-in ARIA attributes, keyboard navigation, and focus management across components like Dialog, DropdownMenu, and Tabs. Document semantic HTML usage, screen reader support, and color contrast compliance via Tailwind. Explain how components handle focus traps, live regions (e.g., for Sonner toasts), and reduced motion preferences via prefers-reduced-motion. Include examples from specific components such as AlertDialog for modal accessibility and Label for form input association. Address testing methods using screen readers and automated tools like Biome a11y checks. Provide guidelines for maintaining accessibility when extending components or creating new ones.

wiki_catalogs.name: Theming & Styling
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for theming and styling architecture. Explain the utility-first approach using Tailwind CSS and how class-variance-authority (cva) in utils.ts enables consistent variant definitions across components. Document dark mode implementation using next-themes and CSS variables in globals.css. Cover the configuration in tailwind.config.mjs for custom colors, fonts (Geist), and animations. Illustrate how component styles are composed using cn() utility for merging conditional classes. Provide examples of extending themes, creating new variants, and ensuring visual consistency. Address performance implications of large CSS bundles and best practices for purging unused styles. Include guidance on accessibility of color palettes and responsive typography scaling.

wiki_catalogs.name: API Integration Patterns
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create API documentation for external service integration patterns in code-speeder. Focus on the transcription service integration point via the transcribeAudio callback in useAudioRecording. Document the expected interface: accepting an audio Blob, returning a Promise with transcription text. Explain the data flow from recording completion to service invocation, including error handling and loading states. Cover the use of fetch or WebSocket for sending audio data and receiving results. Include security considerations like API key management and CORS configuration. Provide client implementation guidelines for integrating with services like Whisper, Deepgram, or Google Speech-to-Text. Address rate limiting, retry logic, and offline fallback strategies. Offer performance optimization tips for large audio uploads and streaming transcription.

wiki_catalogs.name: Development Environment Setup
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for development environment configuration. Detail the setup process including installing pnpm, running initial setup commands, and configuring IDE support for TypeScript and Biome. Explain the purpose of biome.json for linting and formatting rules, and how to run 'pnpm lint' and 'pnpm format'. Cover TypeScript configuration in tsconfig.json, particularly path aliases (@/*) and React 19 compatibility. Document Next.js compiler options in next.config.ts for React Compiler optimization. Address workspace configuration via pnpm-workspace.yaml for monorepo potential. Provide troubleshooting guidance for common issues like Biome not recognizing globals, TypeScript type errors, or ESLint conflicts. Include best practices for maintaining code quality and consistency across the team.

wiki_catalogs.name: Deployment Options
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for deployment options. Describe the Vercel deployment workflow as the primary method, leveraging Next.js optimizations and serverless functions. Document the Docker-based deployment using Dockerfile (multi-stage build) and compose.yaml for container orchestration with potential database integration. Explain environment variable management, port configuration (3001 in start script), and production build process (next build). Cover scaling considerations, caching strategies, and CDN integration. Address security practices for container images and API endpoints. Provide step-by-step deployment guides for both Vercel and self-hosted Docker environments. Include monitoring and logging recommendations for production applications.

wiki_catalogs.name: Contributing Guidelines
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for contributing to the code-speeder project. Provide guidelines for setting up the development environment, running tests (if added later), and formatting code with Biome. Explain the component architecture and how to add new UI components following shadcn/ui patterns using components.json. Document the process for creating new custom hooks in src/hooks with proper TypeScript typing and documentation. Cover coding standards for TypeScript, React best practices, and Tailwind CSS usage. Include instructions for submitting pull requests, writing meaningful commit messages, and updating documentation. Address code review expectations and maintainability practices. Provide examples of good contributions, such as adding a new form component or enhancing audio visualization features.

wiki_overview.content:
<blog>
# Comprehensive Project Analysis: Code-Speeder

## 1. Project Introduction

**Purpose Statement**:  
The `code-speeder` project is a modern web application built with Next.js, designed to provide a fast, responsive, and accessible user interface with rich interactive components. The application appears to be focused on enhancing developer productivity, potentially serving as a tool for rapid prototyping or code generation.

**Core Goals and Objectives**:  
- Deliver a high-performance frontend experience using React 19 and Next.js 16
- Implement a comprehensive UI component library with accessibility and responsiveness in mind
- Support real-time audio input and visualization features
- Enable seamless integration with external transcription services
- Provide a scalable, maintainable architecture using modern tooling

**Target Audience**:  
- Frontend developers and UI engineers
- AI/ML developers integrating voice-to-text capabilities
- Teams building design systems or component libraries
- Developers seeking a modern Next.js starter template with advanced UI capabilities

---

## 2. Technical Architecture

### Component Breakdown

The project follows a modular architecture typical of modern Next.js applications with a strong emphasis on component reusability and separation of concerns:

- **App Router Structure**: Uses Next.js App Router with `src/app` directory
- **UI Component Library**: Comprehensive set of reusable components in `src/components/ui`
- **Hooks System**: Custom React hooks for audio recording, mobile detection, and clipboard operations
- **Utility Layer**: Shared utilities for class composition and audio processing
- **Configuration**: Modern tooling with Biome, Tailwind CSS, and TypeScript

### Design Patterns

- **Component Composition**: Extensive use of the compound component pattern and slot pattern
- **Atomic Design**: UI components organized in a scalable, reusable manner
- **Client-Server Boundary**: Clear separation between server components and client components (using `"use client"`)
- **State Management**: React hooks for local state with potential for external service integration

### System Relationships

```mermaid
flowchart TD
  A[Client Browser] --> B[Next.js App Router]
  B --> C[Layout Component]
  C --> D[Page Components]
  D --> E[UI Components]
  E --> F[Radix UI Primitives]
  D --> G[Custom Hooks]
  G --> H[Audio Recording]
  H --> I[MediaStream API]
  G --> J[Clipboard API]
  D --> K[Utility Functions]
  K --> L[Tailwind Merge]
  K --> M[Clsx]
```

---

## 3. Key Implementation

### Main Entry Points
- `src/app/page.tsx`: Primary application page
- `src/app/layout.tsx`: Root layout with font and CSS configuration
- `src/app/globals.css`: Global styling with Tailwind integration

### Core Modules
- `src/components/ui/`: Comprehensive UI component library
- `src/hooks/`: Custom React hooks for enhanced functionality
- `src/lib/`: Shared utility functions and audio processing

### Configuration Approach
- `next.config.ts`: Next.js configuration with React Compiler enabled
- `tsconfig.json`: TypeScript configuration with path aliases
- `components.json`: shadcn/ui configuration for component management
- `biome.json`: Code quality and formatting configuration

### External Dependencies
- **UI Framework**: Radix UI primitives with shadcn/ui component library
- **Styling**: Tailwind CSS with class-variance-authority and tailwind-merge
- **Animation**: Framer Motion for advanced animations
- **Forms**: React Hook Form with Zod validation
- **Charts**: Recharts for data visualization
- **Icons**: Lucide React

### Integration Points
- Web Audio API for audio recording and visualization
- MediaDevices API for microphone access
- Clipboard API for copy functionality
- Potential transcription service integration via `transcribeAudio` callback

### Component Relationship Diagram

```mermaid
graph TD
  A[RootLayout] --> B[Page Component]
  B --> C[UI Components]
  C --> D[Radix UI Primitives]
  B --> E[Custom Hooks]
  E --> F[useAudioRecording]
  F --> G[recordAudio]
  F --> H[MediaStream]
  E --> I[useMobile]
  E --> J[useCopyToClipboard]
  F --> K[AudioVisualizer]
  K --> L[Canvas API]
  C --> M[Utility Functions]
  M --> N[cn function]
  N --> O[tailwind-merge]
  N --> P[clsx]
```

---

## 4. Key Features

### Functionality Overview

1. **Responsive UI Framework**: Comprehensive component library with dark mode support
2. **Audio Recording & Visualization**: Real-time audio input with visual feedback
3. **Accessibility Features**: Built on Radix UI primitives for maximum accessibility
4. **Developer Experience**: Modern tooling with Biome, React Compiler, and TypeScript
5. **Mobile Optimization**: Responsive design with mobile detection hook

### Implementation Highlights

- **Audio Processing Pipeline**: The project implements a sophisticated audio processing system that captures microphone input, visualizes audio frequencies in real-time, and supports transcription integration.
- **Component Architecture**: Uses the `cva` (Class Variance Authority) pattern for consistent styling variants across components.
- **React Compiler**: Enabled in Next.js configuration for optimized rendering performance.
- **Path Aliasing**: Uses `@/*` aliases for cleaner imports throughout the codebase.

### Feature Architecture: Audio Recording System

```mermaid
stateDiagram-v2
  [*] --> Idle
  Idle --> Recording: toggleListening(true)
  Recording --> Processing: stopRecording()
  Processing --> Transcribing: transcribeAudio()
  Transcribing --> Idle: onTranscriptionComplete()
  Recording --> Idle: Error
  Processing --> Idle: Error
  Transcribing --> Idle: Error
  
  note right of Recording
    - MediaStream active
    - AudioVisualizer rendering
    - Recording in progress
  end note
  
  note right of Transcribing
    - Blob sent to transcription service
    - Loading state displayed
    - Final text processing
  end note
```

### UI Component Architecture

```mermaid
classDiagram
  class Button {
    +variant: "default"|"destructive"|"outline"|"secondary"|"ghost"|"link"
    +size: "default"|"sm"|"lg"|"icon"
    +asChild: boolean
    +className: string
  }
  
  class AudioVisualizer {
    +stream: MediaStream | null
    +isRecording: boolean
    +onClick: () => void
  }
  
  class useAudioRecording {
    +isListening: boolean
    +isRecording: boolean
    +isTranscribing: boolean
    +audioStream: MediaStream | null
    +toggleListening(): void
    +stopRecording(): Promise<void>
  }
  
  class cn {
    +...inputs: ClassValue[]
    +returns: string
  }
  
  Button --> cn : uses
  AudioVisualizer --> useAudioRecording : receives props
  useAudioRecording --> cn : uses for class composition
  useAudioRecording --> "src/lib/audio-utils" : imports recordAudio
```

Sources:
- [package.json](c:\Users\Farooq\Documents\AI Agent\code-speeder\package.json)
- [next.config.ts](c:\Users\Farooq\Documents\AI Agent\code-speeder\next.config.ts)
- [tsconfig.json](c:\Users\Farooq\Documents\AI Agent\code-speeder\tsconfig.json)
- [layout.tsx](c:\Users\Farooq\Documents\AI Agent\code-speeder\src\app\layout.tsx)
- [page.tsx](c:\Users\Farooq\Documents\AI Agent\code-speeder\src\app\page.tsx)
- [button.tsx](c:\Users\Farooq\Documents\AI Agent\code-speeder\src\components\ui\button.tsx)
- [utils.ts](c:\Users\Farooq\Documents\AI Agent\code-speeder\src\lib\utils.ts)
- [components.json](c:\Users\Farooq\Documents\AI Agent\code-speeder\components.json)
- [use-mobile.ts](c:\Users\Farooq\Documents\AI Agent\code-speeder\src\hooks\use-mobile.ts)
- [audio-visualizer.tsx](c:\Users\Farooq\Documents\AI Agent\code-speeder\src\components\ui\audio-visualizer.tsx)
- [use-audio-recording.ts](c:\Users\Farooq\Documents\AI Agent\code-speeder\src\hooks\use-audio-recording.ts)

</blog>
